sec.p: 23–25 January 2013, Kona, Hawaii. 14th International Conference on Autism, Intellectual Disability and Developmental Disabilities. This conference will integrate research and practice, reflecting the need for evidence-based strategies and interventions within this diverse field. Topics include: autism spectrum disorder; multiple disabilities; assistive technology/digital technology; intellectual disability; mental health/dual diagnosis; and transitions. For further information contact: Cindy Perras. E-mail: cindy.perras@cogeco.ac, or visit: http://www.cvent.com/events/14th-international-cec-dadd-conference-on-autism-intellectual-disability-and-developmental-disabilit/event-summary-5c30f87c95514b029021c518c55c89bf.aspx.

6–8 February 2013, Scandic Copenhagen Hotel, Copenhagen, Denmark. Faculty of Forensic Psychiatry Annual Conference 2013. For further information, including a booking form and program visit: http://www.rcpsych.ac.uk/eventsandcourses/facultysectionconferences/forensic2013.aspx.

13–16 February 2013, San Antonio, TX. Learning Disabilities Association of America 50th Annual International Conference. Features over 200 workshops and exhibitions. Discover the latest in learning disability (LD) research; learn effective teaching techniques and strategies; hear from leading experts in the LD field; network with colleagues and make new friends; learn about critical policy issues; earn graduate and/or continuing education credits (CEUs). For further information visit: http://www.ldanatl.org/conference/index.asp.

25–26 February 2013, Hotel Fort Canning, Singapore. 2nd Annual International Conference on Cognitive and Behavioral Psychology. This conference aims to bring together the world’s leading researchers, engineers, and scientists whose professional interests involve psychological theories and practices. The conference will also provide a valuable opportunity for psychology professionals from different cultural backgrounds and diverse fields to explore the global impact of psychology as a field of practice on community and individual mental health care. Themes include: perception; consciousness; language; memory; addictions; learning disabilities/difficulties; eating disorders; depression; and ethics and practice. For further information visit: http://www.cognitive-behavior.org/index.html.

27 February–2 March 2013, The Westin Bayshore, Vancouver, BC, Canada. The 5th International Conference on Fetal Alcohol Spectrum Disorder – Research: Results and relevance. Integrating research, policy, and promising practice around the world. This conference brings together experts from multiple disciplines to share international research, to discuss the implications of this research, and to promote scientific/community collaboration. It provides an opportunity to expand our understanding of the relationships between knowledge and research, and how this can apply to critical actions related to fetal alcohol spectrum disorder (FASD). For the past 10 years, the conference has brought together people passionate about this area of work and provided a stimulating environment for them to make new connections and partnerships. For further information visit: http://www.interprofessional.ubc.ca/FASD/default.asp.

5–6 March 2013, Harrogate International Centre, Harrogate, North Yorkshire, UK. Professional Conference 2013 hosted by the National Autistic Society. The theme of this year’s conference is celebrating creativity and innovation. Keynote sessions will be given by top international speakers who will present an overview of the changing autism environment. There will be a series of expert seminars that will provide you with practical strategies to implement with your colleagues. Personal perspectives will be shared by world-famous author Rudy Simone and renowned autism speaker Dean Beadle. For further information visit: http://www.autism.org.uk/conferences/Professional2013.

8–10 March 2013, Lucknow, India. International Conference on Cerebral Palsy and Developmental Diseases. The theme for this conference is – from Dogmas Towards Evidence. There will be preconference and postconference workshops. This meeting will include delegates from education, services, administration, neurology, neurosurgery, nursing, nutrition, occupational therapy, orthopedic surgery, physiatry, physical therapy, psychiatry, psychology, physical medicine and rehabilitation, public health, social workers, speech and language pathologists, orthotist, and prosthetists all involved in the care of children with such problems, it will also look into care giving throughout the life span and adolescent issues especially in context to Asia. For further information contact: Dr Vipul Shah. E-mail: vipulshak@rediffmail.com, or visit: www.indiancerebralpalsy.com and http://www.indiancerebralpalsy.com/index.php?page=edu.

15 March 2013, Weber State University in Ogden, Utah, USA. Learning Disabilities Association of Utah (LDAU) 2013 conference. Theme for this conference is “Reaching and Teaching Individuals with Learning Disabilities”. For further information contact: E-mail: presenters@ldau.org, or visit: http://www.ldau.org/newsevents/2013presenters/.

21–22 March 2013, University of Cumbria, Lancaster campus, UK. Positive Choices: Positive voices, personalisation and Health. ‘Positive Choices’ is a national event and the only dedicated conference for student learning disability nurses in the country. It provides an opportunity for students to meet with like-minded people from all over the United Kingdom; sharing tips for good practice, gaining a different perspective on learning disability nursing from other areas and celebrating the real difference that learning disability nurses make to people’s lives. For further information visit: http://www.positivechoices.org.uk/conference.html.

4–5 April 2013, venue To Be Confirmed. 12th International Conference on the Care and Treatment of Offenders with Learning Disability. Hosted by the National Autistic Society. This 2-day conference is recognized as the foremost opportunity, in the United Kingdom and internationally, for reflection and sharing for services providing care for the Learning Disabled Offender, both in the public and independent health and social care sectors and the criminal justice system. The conference, and its published proceedings, creates a platform for this speciality and is often regarded as a minority interest by both health and criminal justice mainstream services. Features presentations from eminent international speakers as well as smaller scale research and innovations in the concurrent sessions, this conference will provide delegates with an opportunity to learn new strategies and share good practice. The conference also offers unparalleled networking opportunities for delegates from the United Kingdom and overseas. For further information visit: http://www.autism.org.uk/news-and-events/nas-conferences/upcoming-conferences/care-and-treatment-of-offenders.aspx.

9–11 April 2013, Harrogate International Centre and Holiday Inn, Harrogate, UK. 2013 British Psychological Society Annual Conference. Themes are: the typical and atypical mind across the lifespan; education, ethics and professional practice dilemmas in psychology; and the nature and diversity of social cohesion and attachment. For further information contact: E-mail: annualconference@bps.org.uk or Tel.: +44-(0)116-252-9555, or visit: http://www.bps.org.uk/ac2013.

15–17 April 2013, Coral Beach Hotel in Paphos, Cyprus. First Genetic and epigenetic networks in cognitive dysfunction (GENCODYS) International Conference – Integrative Networks in Intellectual Disabilities. This is the start of a series of Conferences on Cognitive Disorders with a multidisciplinary approach to be hosted every 2 years. There will be approximately 20 keynote speakers selected based on recent work and submitted abstracts. For further information contact: Dik Hagenbeek. E-mail: D.Hagenbeek@gen.umcn.nl or Tel.: +31-243655299, or visit: http://www.paoheyendael.nl/gencodys.

23–25 April 2013, King Saud University (KSU), Riyadh, Saudi Arabia. Fourth National Symposium on Informatics – Technologies for Special Needs. The theme for this Symposium is information technology and People with Special Needs. This includes the use of information technology to help people with special needs in areas such as education and health, and best practices in teaching. The symposium aims to highlight the latest research in the field of computers and information technology for people with hearing, sight, and other sensory impairments, motor impairments, memory, learning, and cognitive impairments and individuals with multiple impairments. There is a particular emphasis on the use of computers, networking, and digital information and the development in the technologies. For further information contact: E-mail: nsi@ksu.edu.sa, or visit: http://nsi.ksu.edu.sa/node/1.

29–30 April 2013, Honolulu, Hawaii, USA. Pacific Rim International Conference on Disability and Diversity. The conference encourages and respects voices from ‘diverse’ perspectives across numerous areas, including: voices from persons representing all disability areas; experiences of family members and supporters across all disability areas; responsiveness to diverse cultural and language differences; evidence of researchers and academics studying disability; stories of persons providing powerful lessons; examples of program providers, natural supports and allies of persons with disabilities; and action plans to meet human and social needs in a globalized world. For further information contact: E-mail: prinfo@hawaii.edu, or visit: www.pacrim.hawaii.edu.

2–3 May 2013, Hilton Newcastle Gateshead Hotel, Newcastle, UK. Royal College of Psychiatrists Faculty of Addictions Annual Conference 2013. Session will include clinical skills, latest research, and developments. Preliminary program and registration form will be available soon. For further information contact: E-mail: conference@rcpsych.ac.uk, or visit: http://www.rcpsych.ac.uk/eventsandcourses/facultysectionconferences/addictions2013conference.aspx.

7–9 May 2013, Wildbad Kreuth, Bavaria. Professional Providers and Caregivers Conference ‘Specialised Training for Prader-Willi Syndrome’. This conference follows in the tradition of the previous three, building on the best practice model for caring people with Prader-Willi Syndrome (PWS) in residential care. Speakers come from all over the globe to share, discuss, and work in collaboration searching for the best possible management tools needed for this challenging work. For further information visit: http://www.pws-caretakers-conference.de/.

9–10 May 2013, South of England, venue to be confirmed. BILD Annual Positive Behaviour Support Conference. It is anticipated that this conference will attract a wide range of professionals and individuals who have an interest in this field including people with experience of using services. British Institute of Learning Disabilities (BILD) is keen to encourage presentations from people who have intellectual disabilities, their families, and experience of using services. Themes will include: positive behaviour support for people with intellectual/learning disabilities; positive behaviour support for people with autism; supporting children and young people who exhibit behaviours of risk; therapeutic interventions, behaviour support and the human rights framework; identifying and reducing restrictive practices; developing inclusive educational environments; the voice and experience of people who use services; the voice and experience of the family; and supporting the family. The conference will promote and share international research and practice. For further information visit: http://www.bild.org.uk/our-services/positive-behaviour-support/bilds-pbs-events/.

6–9 June 2013, Milan, Italy. 4th World Congress on ADHD – From Childhood to Adult Disease. For further information visit: http://www.adhd-congress.org/. The Program is due to be published in April 2013.
27–29 June 2013, Boston, Massachusetts, USA. The 37th Annual International Academy for Research in Learning Disabilities Conference. For further information visit: http://www.iarld.com/.

8–13 July 2013, Baltimore, Maryland, USA. AHEAD Conference 2013. The annual international Association on Higher Education and Disability (AHEAD) conference brings together professionals in the fields of higher education and disability for a week of information-sharing, networking, and theoretical and practical training. For further information contact: E-mail: information@ahead.org, or visit: http://www.ahead.org/conferences/future.

17–21 July 2013, Cambridge, UK. International Prader-Willi Syndrome Organisations 8th International PWS Conference. Program will include all the latest research about Prader-Willi Syndrome (PWS) including sessions especially for scientists, researchers, care providers, teachers, and parents. For further information contact: E-mail: jwaters@pwsa.co.uk, or visit: www.pwsa.co.uk.

22–24 August 2013, Tokyo, Japan. International Association for the Scientific Study of Intellectual Disabilities (IASSID) Asia-Pacific 3rd Regional Conference. ‘Multiformity and Diversity – Combining Individual Care and Community-Based Supports’. The conference is held in conjunction with the 48th Annual Meeting of the Japanese Association for the Study of Developmental Disabilities, August 24–25, 2013. For further information visit: www.iassid.org.

13–14 September 2013, Southampton Solent University, East Park Terrace, Southampton, England, UK. Learning Disabilities Worldwide 2013 World Congress on Learning Disabilities. Further information will be posted on Web site: http://www.ldworldwide.org/ldwr-world-congress-on-learning-disabilities.

7–11 October 2013, New Delhi, India. Asian Federation for the Intellectually Disabled (AFID) – Conference 2013: Towards dignity and quality of life – ‘Evolving individual capacity with family and community’. For further information visit: http://www.handiplanet-echanges.info/en/node/27043.
9–11 September 2014, Lancaster University, UK. Disability Studies Conference. Further information to follow.

6–11 June 2015, Berlin, Germany. 8th World Congress of the International Society of Physical and Rehabilitation Medicine. Hosted by German Society for Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation; Austrian Society for Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation. There will be leading experts in Physical and Rehabilitation Medicine from all over the world. In the congress, the most recent scientific studies in Physical and Rehabilitation Medicine will be presented and discussed and innovation in rehabilitation measures and technology will be the focus of the conference. There will also be seminars and hands-on-workshops. Innovation of rehabilitation technology will also be presented in an extensive industrial exhibition. For further information contact: E-mail: Jena at jutta.vach@conventus.de, or visit: http://www.isprm2015.org/.
6–8 September 2016, Lancaster University, UK. Disability Studies Conference. Further information to follow.
